awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Genomic and phenotypic analyses of color pattern divergence in a mimetic radiation of poison frogs
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature abounds with organisms that display bright colors, yet it is not always obvious why. Some animals evolve to advertise to potential predators that they are poisonous (warning coloration). Different toxic species may converge on the same color pattern, giving both an advantage by more effectively advertising to predators. This is known as Müllerian mimicry, a focus of interest because it involves multiple phenomena that lie at the heart of our understanding of evolutionary processes. The genetic basis of mimicry is of special interest, because it provides a window into how these key evolutionary processes unfold. This research will focus on discovering the genetic underpinnings of Müllerian mimicry in a species of poison frog that has undergone an evolutionary radiation across different geographic regions of Peru. In each region, the mimic poison frog has evolved a different color pattern (such as stripes, bands, or spots), to resemble another species in that region. The evolution of these new color patterns may be driving reproductive isolation between populations of the mimic poison frog, leading to speciation and the creation of new biodiversity. The project is a collaborative endeavor between researchers at three large public universities and will involve broad participation by undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral scientist. The results of the project will be used to enhance K12 education through classroom presentations, public lectures and museum displays.
 
This project focuses on four specific aims: 1. Identify key genetic factors involved in color pattern development in the mimic poison frog by investigating differential gene expression across developmental stages and color pattern morphs, using next generation sequencing to produce stage-specific transcriptomes for each morph, which will be assembled to analyze patterns of differential gene expression. 2. Identify the causal gene(s) underlying differences in color pattern between morphs using genome-wide marker arrays (exome capture sequences) to screen transition zone samples (from three transition zones) and enable admixture mapping to discover candidate genes. 3. Test the association of specific candidate loci with color pattern using multigenerational pedigrees. 4. Test specific hypotheses regarding selection and demographic processes in the transition zones and between mimics and models, using new analytical tools. Together these complementary, mutually reinforcing approaches will elucidate the genetic underpinnings and population genomics of color pattern evolution and diversity in this mimetic radiation of poison frogs.

por.por_cntn:
Final Outcomes report

 

A major goal of evolutionary biology is to identify and compare the genetic basis of ecologically important traits, but there are a limited number of systems where the genotype to phenotype link has been clearly elucidated for traits that mediate processes of focal interest to evolutionary biologists, such as aposematism and mimicry. In this project we aim to better understand the genetic basis of color and pattern evolution and convergence in a mimetic radiation of aposematic vertebrate populations: the mimic poison frog of Peru. This species has evolved four different color pattern morphs in four different geographic regions in northern Peru, each which mimics a different model species. This project 1) conducts an in-depth evaluation of the molecular genetic basis of color pattern development and divergence in these poison frogs using next-generation genomic methods. 2) Develops of novel quantitative methods to discover and analyze the association between specific loci and specific aspects of color pattern in these frogs, and 3) develops and deploys of population genomic methods to assess the factors driving divergence between color pattern morphs in different geographic regions, and the potential contribution of such divergence to incipient speciation.

 

To accomplish these goals, we have generated substantial genomic resources which are all publicly available. These resources include a transcriptome and an annotated genome assembly, as well as a large gene expression dataset generated from skin patches of different colors from different morphs. These resources allowed us to identify the genes which are responsible for color and color patterning. Specifically, we used a selection approach with the transcriptome data, and complemented this with an exome capture data set on pedigreed lab population. To the exome capture data, we applied association tests using both divergence mapping and admixture mapping to identify candidate color pattern genes. We also focused on adaptive introgression and selection analyses to investigate patterns of selection on specific genes, and related population genomic analyses. All these data are (or will be) publicly available.  

 

The pedigree analyses (in progress) detected the association of specific candidate genes with specific aspects of color pattern. For example, the variation in mc1r allele frequency was found to be significantly associated with variation in both dorsal pattern and hind leg coloration, variation in asip allele frequency was found to be significantly associated with dorsal coloration and dorsal color pattern, variation in retsat allele frequency was found to be associated with dorsal coloration, and variation in bsn allele frequency was significantly associated with dorsal color pattern.

In addition to the substantial scientific goals, the project also had specific training goals which ended up being very successful. The research group has trained dozens of undergraduates, 8-10 graduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher (that now has a tenure track appointment). Many of these students were from traditionally underrepresented groups. Students received training in fieldwork in the tropics, animal husbandry, molecular genetic lab work, and bioinformatic analyses
